case_vignette: A 21-year-old male presents for evaluation of a painful rash on his right index finger. He reports a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. He denies any trauma or topical products applied to the area. He has a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful rash on my right index finger that started with tingling and now has red small spots that turned yellow and pus-filled.
Has the rash spread to other parts of your body or is it localized to your index finger?
The rash is localized to my right index finger.
Do you remember any recent injuries or insect bites to that finger?
No, I haven't had any recent injuries or applied any products to that area.
Do you have any known allergies or medical conditions?
I have a history of cold sores on my lips.
Final Diagnosis: Herpetic Whitlow
